bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, November 9, 1950

div1.p: Hench informs Siler that it will be impossible for him to attend the upcoming meeting of the Reed Memorial Association. However, he hopes to attend again in the future.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to J.F. Siler, November 9, 1950
div1.opener:
November 9, 1950
Colonel J. F. Siler
1835 Eye Street N.W.
Washington 6, D. C.
My dear Colonel Siler:
div1.p:
I have just returned home to find
distressingly voluminous correspondence. I am
faced with the necessity of turning right around
and going back to Europe to receive the Nobel
award with Doctor Kendall on December 10. I
have to write between now and then a “Nobel
Oration.” In addition to that, because of
another award and ceremony, I have to be in
New York for just a few hours on November 20 and
then rush right back again.

It will therefore be impossible for me
to stop in Washington this fall, even for an hour.
I regret this greatly as the work of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association is very dear to my heart. As
soon as the present tension relaxes (and it will relax
I hope within a few months) I hope once more to be
very closely identified with the Association and plan
to meet with it every year that I can.

If you and I can accomplish anything by
correspondence, please let me try to do so.

Thank you for your kind comments regarding
the Nobel Prize. We receive it with great pleasure and
also humility because we know how much remains to be
learned. It is an award for the Mayo Foundation and
the Clinic more than for me personally.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
